projectDesc.p: To the tune “Stop Your Horse and Listen”—"Phoenix Pillows" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the tune “Stop Your Horse and Listen”—"Phoenix Pillows"
Phoenix pillows and peacock curtains.
For two or three years,
We were as intimate as fish and water.
Good days and fine times,
Deep affection and profuse love,
I did nothing but following her wishes.
How come she
Indulges herself
So excessively?
For no reason, she fries me,
A thousand, ten thousand times —
Otherwise how could I bear to leave her?
Yet now the more I travel, the further away she is.
I gradually realized that, even though I regret leaving her, the past can never be retrieved.
It is pointless to send letters and messages,
In the end, what will it do?
I also considered restoring our intimacy,
But I cannot help but think twice.
Even if we reunite,
I am afraid our love
Could hardly be what it was.
